ExplanationOfAllophones: Spirantization of intervocalic /g/ to ɣ is fairly common, though not obligatory, when intervocalic within a word and flanked by vowels from the set {a ɔ}.

Comments: h occurs in loans, chiefly from Fulfulde

ʔ (glottal stop) is found in gúrùʔá:nà ‘Koran (book)’, where it reflects Arabic ʔ, and in the semi-linguistic utterance ɔⁿ́ ʔɔⁿ̀ ‘nope!’. A glottal stop is also inserted after a v- (for Cv-) reduplicative segment before a vowel-initial stem

ExplanationOfAllophones: The [nasalization] spreading occurs over intervening vowels

There is much fluctuation between the two short high vowels... My general sense is that short high vowels in noninitial syllables of verb stems tend toward unrounded [i] when adjacent segments are not rounded or labial.
At the end of a word, a mora is added to a final short-voweled Cv syllable, lengthening its vowel, to allow a contour (i.e. non-level) tone to be articulated with ease.
The [nasalization] spreading occurs over intervening vowels

Comments: Contour-toned syllables usually have at least two moras... Exceptions are Cv̌ verb stems

ExplanationOfAllophones: Another type of final <LH>-to-H raising affects final rising-toned long vowels in nonmonosyllabic stems that are followed by a word beginning in an H-tone... The raising seems to be most consistent before monosyllabic postpositions... and similar clitic-like elements, but it is at least optional in some other combinations.
